Analysis:
- My head is at (8,4). Enemy head is at (6,3). Both snakes are length 1 (no bodies), so there is no immediate body collision risk.
- Legal moves: UP -> (8,5), DOWN -> (8,3), LEFT -> (7,4), RIGHT -> (9,4). None are off-board or into bodies.
- The apple at (6,4) is 1 step from the enemy (he can take it by going UP). It's 2 steps from me (would require LEFT then LEFT), so contesting it is risky — enemy has the immediate advantage.
- Moving LEFT would close distance to the enemy and to that contested apple, increasing risk of interaction. Moving RIGHT goes toward the board edge and limits options. Moving DOWN goes away from the dense apple area.
- Moving UP to (8,5) keeps many follow-up options (UP/LEFT/RIGHT/DOWN), moves me towards a cluster of apples to the north (e.g., (8,7), (6,5), (5,6)), and avoids walking into the enemy's neighborhood where he can claim the nearby apple quickly.

Short-term plan (for next few turns):
- Move UP now to (8,5). From there aim for (8,7) or swing west toward the cluster around (6,5)/(5,6) depending on enemy moves.
- Avoid moving into tight areas near the enemy; prefer staying in open space with multiple escape options to reduce chance of head-on or trap.
- If the enemy commits to the (6,4) apple and grows, give him space and collect less-contested apples to build an advantage.
